vectorData.altText: That’s right!  The insula is a cortical region hidden within the lateral fissure.
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

superior longitudinal fasciculus. Expose the fibers of the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus (association fibres) in the occipital lobe.  The inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus, like the corona radiata, lies on a deeper plane relative to the superior longitudinal fasciculus.
Next, expose the corona radiata (projection fibres) deep to the

This figure illustrates an intermediate dissection demonstrating the corona radiata and part of the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus. A segment of the superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF) has been left to illustrate its relative position.  
Notice the insula. Before you proceed with thedissection, it’s important to remind you about the insula and its relationship to thestructures deep to it.

R. cerebral hemisphere, lateral  view, intermediate dissection.
From Serial Dissections of the Human Brain, by Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D., © 1981 by Gage.
The insula revealed by dissection of the cortex above and below the lateral fissure.

Left cerebral hemisphere, coronal section.
From Serial Dissections of the Human Brain, by Carlton G. Smith, M.D., Ph.D., © 1981 by Gage.

On the right is a coronal section through the left cerebral hemisphere. Labelled are the white matter tracts: the corpus callosum (A), the corona radiata (B), the internal capsule (C) and the external capsule (D). The lateral fissure is indicated with a red dotted line, and is shown separating the frontal lobe from the temporal lobe. Notice the insula in the depths of the lateral fissure. Question: your next step will be to remove the insula; What white matter structure will you reveal? It is named above.
Think then click!
Deep to the insula, you will find the external capsule.
